item.description:
A card game of superhero combat. Each player uses a custom deck of cards which represents all of the members and powers of one Superhero Team.

Each deck has forty cards to represent the four team members. There are ten cards for each Superhero, five Character Cards and five Ability Cards. Each card has a force value of 1 to 5. A player tries to knock out opposing Superheroes by playing cards with a higher total force value than those played by the opposing player.

"You win if you KO all of your opponents Superheroes."

A simple tactical game of fantasy combat between individual wizards and warriors. It has nothing to do with Sword & Sorcery.

The game is played on a hex map with spaces large enough to accommodate miniature figures.

Characters are rated for Attack, Damage, Defend, Hits, Speed, and Range (hand to hand). Warriors carry a magical melee weapon with a randomly determined special ability. Wizards have a randomly determined assortment of spells.

Characters earn experience by defeating opponents. Experience can be used to enhance traits or to acquire additional spells.

"Combat rules for cute animae mini monsters." An expansion for Superhero Slugfest, the quick and dirty tactical rules for superhero combat.

The game is played on a hex map with spaces large enough to accommodate miniature figures.

Supercritters are rated for Attack, Damage, Defend, Hits, Speed, and Range (hand to hand). Each Supercritter also has ten super powers. Stats are included for three Supercritter teams. Evolution rules provide for Supercritter experience and advancement.

"Basic scenario objectives: Each side picks or creates a team. Combat may be one on one or a free for all. Match Locations: Critter Combat Arena, The Mall, School yard, etc."

"Quick & Dirty Tactical Space Fighter Combat Rules. Special rules for pilots: 10 Skills, Panic, Quirks, Special maneuvers. Very easy ship construction system."

"A space hex map is required. Use painted miniatures or chits to represent ships. 10 and 6 sided dice are used."

The rules cover concepts such as stealth, detection, missiles, guns, morale, factions, and formations. There is also a random skirmish scenario generator.

"Wargame for 2+ players. Players control bands of warriors in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. Eclectic unit types with a wide range of technologies."

"Victory: Wipe your enemies off the face of whats left of the earth. Or capture all the Towns or kill all enemy Heroes."

"Players a rival kings in the land of Sumeria."

The game is played on a hex map depicting the Fertile Crescent between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. There are ten City States on the map: Kish, Larak, Nippur, Umma, Lagash, Uruk, Ur, Eshnunna, Khafaje, and Eridu.

"Victory: The first player to control six of the ten city-states is the winner."

A game of interplanetary warfare where the goal is to destroy all of your opponent's planets. This is done with Planet Busters, a powerful weapon carried by certain types of spaceships.

Components include a hex mapsheet, ten and six sided dice, and an assortment of counters. Common counters include Resource counters, Planet Buster counters, and the 84 Ship counters. In addition, each player has Fleet counters and Planet counters in a unique color.

There are twenty-one ship types in the game. Players build new spaceships by expending Resource counters. Resource counters are earned by controlling planets.

"Abstract WWII Naval Strategy Game."

The pieces represent seven types of ships: PT Boat, Submarine, Destroyer, Frigate, Cruiser, Battleship, and Carrier. Each unit is individually rated for hits, movement, range, damage, and number of attacks.

"Use an 8 x 8 or larger square or hex map. All ships can move and shoot vertical and horizontal but not diagonal. Each side starts with 1 of each ship and 2 destroyers for a total of 8 ships."

"On the Sea map mark several spaces as land obstacles. Ships cannot move over land but they can shoot over it. Torpedo attacks cannot be made over land."

"Objective: Completely destroy all enemy ships."

A semi-historical game/simulation, in the style of En Garde!, representing the experiences a British Naval Officer might have faced in the Napoleonic era as popularly depicted in the Horatio Hornblower novels and other media.

By rolling on a series of tables, the player generates advancements, events, and achievements for his character. "Keep track of Prizes, Engagements fought, and Total Merits received as well as Rank. Be sure to name the Ships you are posted to."

"Players control Viking clans that raid settlements on the Mainland. The player with the most loot at the end of 20 turns is the winner."

In this simple game of exploration and conquest, the players may build, recruit or buy six types of units: Long Ship, Dragon Ship, Chieftain, Vikings, Berserkers, and Scout. The mainland forces consist of three types of units: Peasant Militia, Men at Arms, and Knights. The number of mainland units encountered depends on the type of settlement discovered. Settlement types include Farm, Village, Church, Town, City, and Castle.

At the start of the game, the land masses on the mapsheet are blank. The terrain and settlements are filled in as the players explore the map.

"Card game for 2-4 players. Early 19th Century Whale Hunting Theme."

"Scale: Each Player represents one Whaling Ship of European/American Identity. One Game represents one Whaling Season."

"Game End: The Game ends when players have gone through the deck twice."

"Victory: At the end of the game the player with the most Blubber Tokens wins."

An optional rule allows they players to represent particular Whaling Nations. There is also a solitaire dice based variant which replaces the cards with tables.

"Two Player Card & Bidding game. Simulation of World War I (The Great War)"

The game last 18 turns, spanning the time period of 1914-1918.

"One Player is the Entente Powers (EP): Britain, France, Russia, Serbia, Italy, Romania, Greece, USA. The other Player is the Central Powers (CP): Austria-Hungary, Germany, Bulgaria, Turkey."

The game is played across six fronts: Western, Eastern, Balkan, Italian, Turkish, and the "War at Sea." There are three Territory Markers at each Front. A Front is captured by winning all three Territory Markers at the Front.

"Victory: The first player to capture the Western Front wins the War. If the EP captures the Eastern Front he wins the War. After 18 turns the player who has captured the most Fronts wins, otherwise it is a Stalemate."

name.value: Julius Caesar: Caesar, Pompey, and the Roman Civil War 49-45 B.C.

item.description:
Julius Caesar is a two-player game, depicting the later Roman civil wars (49-45 BC). The forces of Caesar are pitted against those of Pompey.

From the publisher:
Julius Caesar brings the drama of the Roman Civil War to life. Players take control of the legions of Caesar or Pompey and fight to rule Rome as Emperor.

From the Designer:

Julius Caesar is a card driven block game. You use cards to Move, levy or play an Event. 13 victory point Towns or Cities are depicted on the 17"x 33" (43 x 84 cm) game board of the Mediterranean. Take command of Caesar's Veteran Legions or Pompey sprouting Young Legions around the Mediterranean. You decide how best to defend or conquer the Republic. With endless possibilities at your disposal this game will keep your adrenaline pumping. The only question I have for you, the game player, is, are you ready to prove that you deserve to be Emperor of Rome? Come prove it on the game board!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
"Board & Card game for two players. Based on the Aztec sport of the same name."

The game is played on a 13x7 grid. There are three pawns, one representing the ball and two representing blockers. The movement of the pieces is controlled by card play. All of the pieces may be moved by either player.

"Victory: The first player to score 4 points is the winner. The other player’s team is sacrificed to the gods."

"Tlatelolco was the great market for the Aztec Empire. The Aztecs had no coins; so all trade was by barter. Players are pochteca (merchants) trying to acquire certain goods."

Players move their pochteca around the 8×8 board to visit merchant stands in the market. Each player is attempt to collect six target goods randomly determined for each player. In addition, the players need to avoid the thief who prowls around the marketplace.

"Card game for 2 players. One player is the Achaeans (Greeks). The other player is the Trojans."

Each player uses a unique deck of cards. There are ten types of cards: Hero, Companion, God, Warrior, Strategy, Arms, Event, Trait, Honor and Defenses. Each card is marked with a Force value from 1 to 15. The cards represent specific elements of the Trojan War.

The players attempt to play the highest ranking card combination each hand. The first player to win seven hands wins the game.

"Card game for 2-4+ players. Players are Truck Drivers. Set in the USA in the 1970’s. Heavy on CB Lingo. Players try to complete routes."

The game uses a custom deck of cards with four suits: Rig, City, Haulin, and Smokey. Each card is marked with a number from 1 to 6, which affect how cards can be combined into melds.

When a meld is played, another player may disrupt it with a Smokey card. If the meld is not disrupted, the player who played it marks off one route as completed.

"Winning: The first player to complete 5 Routes is the winner."

name.value: The Mystic Warriors of the Plains

item.description:
"Each player takes the role of an (American) Indian Brave (Young Warrior). Players compete to accumulate prestige by their deeds."

The game uses a custom deck of cards. There are nine types of cards in the deck: Tribe, Weapon, Dress, Approach, Coup, Hunt/Trade, Luck, Spirit, and Trade. The cards are used to engage in various activities.

Players collect Eagle Feathers by participating in raids, which come in four different types: Horse Raids, War Parties, Revenge Raids, and Pipeholder Raids. Players may also hunt, hold tribal gatherings, and trade.

"Victory: The first player to accumulate 28 Eagle Feathers has enough to make his Warbonnet and wins the game."

"Board game for 2+ players. Chinese Three Kingdoms theme. No dice or cards. The Three Empires were the Wei, Shu, & Wu. Each unit represents several hundred soldiers."

The game is played on a 12x12 square grid with ten cities marked on it. There are also ten squares marked as forest and ten marked as mountains. Each player starts in control of a 5x5 corner of the grid.

There are seven types of fighting units in the game: General, Armored Cavalry, Infantry, Archers, Rockets, Shock Troops, and Horse Archers. Each unit is rated for movement, attack range, and defense.

"Victory: Destroy all enemy Generals or occupy all cities."

Kingdoms and Crowns is a board game in the tradition of games such as Talisman. The game is set in a fantasy world of elves and dragons. The premise of the game is that the rule of the realm has died and many parties are now maneuvering their candidates to take the throne. However, absolute power will be difficult to achieve. To become rule of the realm you must have the backing of the most influential powers in the land, but you should also have support form the Otherworld. There is one way to become the undisputed ruler of the realm, and that is to recover a legendary crown that once belonged to the most powerful rule to have ever ruled the land. Legend has it that the crown was stolen and is now somewhere on the Planes of Damnation. Only a hero of great power and skill could ever hope to enter those lands and return. Alternatively it be just simpler to remove the competition.

"Vietnam War tunnel combat. Bluffing game for 2 players. One Player is the US Tunnel Rat. The other player is the VC."

By asking questions, the US player must determine if the VC's current card is a tunnel, Viet Cong unit, or trap. The US player must acquire five tunnel cards before the VC player can inflict five casualties.

"2+ Player card game. Players are Elder Vampires vying to be the uncontested Prince of a city. Based on the White Wolf RPG Vampire the Masquerade and the associated Deckmaster card game Jyhad."

The game uses a custom card deck. There are seven different types of cards: Vampire, Event, Location, Political Organization, Combat Event, Modifier, and Damage.

"Victory: Be the first to control cards with a combined political value of 20+ or kill all the opposing Elder Vampires."

The game of buying and selling industries in the danish town Viborg. Each player controls a car, and opts to buy the best businesses in Viborg to charge fees from the other players. The last player with all the money is the winner.

The game plays very similar to Monopoly.

name.value: The Dangerous Book for Boys Game

item.description:
From the box:

The adventure game based on the best-selling book!

You've been shipwrecked on a deserted island on a deserted island with nothing but your wits and some string to save you. Thank goodness you've been reading your Dangerous Book for Boys! Use your skills to complete solo or group challenges, test your knowledge of facts from the book, or put your mental agility to the test. Each success wins you a puzzle piece so you can "build" a raft and sail off the island. The first adventurer to travel along the whole track and complete their raft can sail away into the sunset in victory!

Girls are invited to play this game too, but they must agree to be honorary boys for the duration of the game by saying: "Boys are fantastic, girls are elastic!" three times.
Bees! is a two-player game played on a hexagonal board. The objective of the game is to capture your opponent's queen, using warriors, drones, and your own queen.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Star Wars The Clone Wars Galactic Heroes Game Clone Trooper vs. Super Battle Droid

item.description:
A children's game (Ages 5 and up) using a small, simple board, a card deck for each figure, dice, and the "Galactic Heroes" toys as playing pieces. In the game each player selects a character and, on his turn, rolls the die and moves on the board. Board spaces tell the players what to do (draw a new card or fight).

The combat system involves each player secretly selecting a card and then comparing the two; the player with the highest value card wins the fight.

The "hit point" system uses two-sided tiles (six for each character) that are placed to show the character healthy. As fights are lost, tiles are flipped to the "damaged" side. Once all six of a character's tiles are flipped over that character is knocked out of the game.

Available in three different versions.

Anakin vs. Dooku
Obi Wan vs. General Grievous
Clone Trooper vs. Super Battle Droid

Each set can be played alone or sets can be combined for larger games.

name.value: World War Two Naval Wargame Rules

item.description: World War Two Naval Wargaming Rules by RA Ellard and JE Hammond published trough both DAVCO and Skytrex (DAVCO later merged with Skytrex). Is small (20 pages including charts) and lightweight set of rules for playing naval surface actions in the period of 1929 till 1952, the era of super-dreadnoughts, using 1/3000th miniatures from Davco/Skytrex.

Time Twist is a print and play game of plotting, stealing and time travel, for 2 to 4 players.

Sunday, November 5th 1899

“When their father, an eccentric scientist, passed away, the four brothers were eager to find out which of them would inherit the family heirloom; a rare collection of antique coins. They were disappointed to discover that their father, knowing how much they all enjoyed games, planned to have his servants hide the coins around the house for a bizarre family treasure hunt.
On Saturday morning the servants hid the antique coins in various locations around the mansion and then the four sons spent the day searching every nook and cranny, desperate to be the one to find the most coins.
By Saturday night one of the sons, much to the annoyance his brothers, had won the game and, having found the most coins, gained a considerable inheritance.

Desperate to get their hands on the inheritance, each of the brothers had the same idea; use their time machines to change the outcome of the game. Based on their father’s prototype, their small time travel devices could enable them to travel back no further than a couple of days. Even the winner of the contest, suspicious of his scheming brothers, realised that he should also travel back to make sure that he was still victorious.

The plan was to ask the servants where the coins had been hidden, as it was now Sunday they would be happy to divulge that information. Armed with this knowledge the brothers would then travel back to Saturday morning and claim a coin from its hiding place.”

Taking on the role of one of the brothers, you will gain a clue card and then travel back to Saturday to claim a coin. You will have to then return to Sunday to acquire another clue card.
Other players can use game cards to steal coins from you. Stealing can be blocked by using a trap (a Time Twist) which you set up on Friday – you must of course remember to travel back to Friday to set that trap up or it will never happen!
Avoid being lost in space and time as you manipulate time and use every low down trick you can think of to claim your rightful inheritance.

The necessary game files can be purchased from http://www.wargamedownloads.com/item.php?item=739&pics=
 Players will need to provide a 6 sided die, 14 plastic stands (these are optional).

From the publisher:

"Enjoy learning the aleph-bet as you race around the board!"

Players must try and collect the 32 aleph-bet letter cards that are placed on the board. There is one landing space for each of the letters (as well as a few follow-the-instructions spaces). The first person to land on a given space takes the card for that letter.

The game ends when the first players reaches the finish line. The winner is the player with the most number of cards.

Mormon Trek is a simple roll-and-move designed to promote family discussion about the Mormon Pioneers experiences. Each game piece is a rocking chair that is being carried across the plains in wagon trains. Movement is dictated by die-roll with a custom dice featuring wagons, blessings, and tribulations. A wagon roll simple allows you to move forward. A blessing roll (golden key) lets you move to a special section of the board where you talk about blessings the pioneers experienced. A tribulation roll moves you backwards and requires you to talk about a trial the pioneers experienced.

The first player to successfully travel from Nauvoo, IL to Salt Lake City, UT is the winner.

From the publisher "Have you always wanted to be Miss Scarlet or Professor Plum?... Well now is your chance. Become your favourite character with this Cluedo game for adults. Cluedo Party is the perfect accompaniment to host your very own murder mystery dinner party, containing everything you need including, guest invites, character profiles, dressing up bibs and a CD containing another murder mystery for 8 guests. A Cluedo game for adults. The first chance to become your favourite Cluedo character and solve the murder mystery with the added value of a second murder mystery on the CD."

Hasbro try to get into the host-a-murder-party genre with this version of their popular Cluedo franchise. The game box is not large though, so do not expect a lot of props. The box photos show people dressed up as the characters, but the bibs actually provided may underwhelm you. Recommended age 12+.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: This is a domino game where words are used instead of pips. Each domino is divided into two colors: white and purple. Each side has a word on the top part of the domino and a shape on the bottom. Dominoes are played from a players hand against other dominoes that rhyme. The shapes on the bottom are used to determine whether the words rhyme and the object of the game is to exhaust your hand of dominoes. The dominoes in the box are larger than ordinary dominoes and are made from very thick card stock.

Trivia New Mexico is a trivia game based on New Mexico facts, history, entertainment and current events. Players move around a board representative of businesses and companies in New Mexico as of 1994 (some of these companies do not exist anymore). Different areas have special effects on players (ala Monopoly) and will require participants to answer questions to from a total of five categories. These answers are used to complete a score card and the first person or team to cross the finish line with a complete score card wins.

A variant to "dots and boxes", where each player has a stack of numbered tiles. Players take turns to mark a box side with one of their tiles. The player that completes a box must use one of their tiles to claim it. You score the total of the sides of the box. Highest score at the end of the game wins.

Observation game to play while traveling. Players are dealt a hand of cards. As soon as they see something that corresponds to one of their cards, they announce and remove it. Get rid of your cards to win.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Players have a fixed stack of tiles comprising single digits and simple mathematical operators. In turn, they lay tiles to form an equality, which must (after the first play) link with one already on the board. Fewest tiles remaining at the end of the game is the winner.

name.value: Der Dativ ist dem Genitiv sein Tod: Das große Spiel

item.description:
Based on the popular series of books on German grammar by Bastian Sick, "Der Dativ ist dem Genitiv sein Tod".

Playing as a group, in pairs or as individuals, players attempt to navigate the maze of German language by answering questions on grammar. Movement around the board is limited by the players' confidence in their answer (50-100%). If they answer correctly, they may move forward, but a wrong answer sees them moving back.

See also Der Dativ ist dem Genitiv sein Tod

link.value: Der Dativ ist dem Genitiv sein Tod

item.description: Rhode Island Monopoly combines the classic game of Monopoly with a Rhode Island touch. Well-known Rhode Island based businesses replace the properties and even the community chests.

The Kingdom is at the brink of civil war. Diplomats and Chancellors from different parts of the land have come to the King's court to solve the conflicts between the different opposing factions. However, among the Diplomats there is a Traitor - with chaos in his mind. If he can turn the other Diplomats at each other, or eliminate enough Chancellors, total chaos will erupt in the Kingdom, and the Traitor will be greatly rewarded...

At the beginning of the game players are secretly assigned the roles of one Traitor the rest being Senators. Each player receives three advisers (that act like life points) and a counter is placed in the middle of a 20 or 30 (depending on # of players) diplomatic point track. The Senators win by taking the point count to 30 or eliminating the Traitor's all three advisers. The Traitor wind respectively by taking the point count to 0 or when all the advisers of a senator have been eliminated.

The heart of the game lies in negotiation and bluffing. The game is played using action cards that manipulate the diplomatic point track, number of advisers in the game and the ever useful resource of gold. Much like in Werewolf, the task of the Traitor is to turn the Senators against one other while getting away with actions with which he tries to end the game in his favour.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This game is played on a board with 10 x 10 squares. The goal of the game is to create a line (horizontal, vertical or diagonal) on the board that contains one of each number (the sum of which equals 45, hence the name of the game).

Each player has a rack with ten numbers on it. Each turn, he may take one of two actions:
1) Draw a new tile, and:
a) Place a tile from his rack on the board, and add the newly drawn tile to his rack, or;
b) Place the newly drawn tile on the board;
2) Take a tile from the board and replace it with a tile from his rack.

Whenever a tile is placed on the board, it may not be placed in a row that already contains the same number. The round ends when a player manages to complete one row on the board (or two, in a two player game) while also having completed 'row' on his rack. All players now score points, and a new round starts. The game continues until a agreed-upon number of rounds has been played, or an agreed-upon score is reached.

Home page: http://www.gameof45.com/

Mythos Miniatures is a self-published skirmish game set in Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos universe. The mechanics are based on Graeme Dawson's DWMG engine. It is a character driven system more akin to RPGs like Trail of Cthulhu and Call of Cthulhu than wargames.

Miniatures must be bought separately from other companies, such as eM-4 Miniatures, RAFM, Hasslefree and Shadowforge (or any of the licenced Call of Cthulhu Miniatures ranges).

New York: December 16-17, 1835
Chicago: October 8-10, 1871 
Boston: November 9-10, 1872
Seattle: June 6, 1889
San Francisco: April 18-21, 1906

What do all these dates have in common? They mark some of the most catastrophic fires in U.S. history in which thousands and thousands of lives were lost, and enormous sections of these major metropolitans were reduced to little more than ash and amber.

Most city building games require construction from the ground up. But with 'Great Fires', players find out what happens when their beautiful city is, in its prime, under siege of fires raging out of control.

Great Fires is a fast paced game where the object is to be the least devastated of all players at the end of the game. Each player chooses one city (New York, Chicago, Boston, Seattle or San Francisco) and each game the fires begin in different districts. The mechanics for the spreading of fires can be fierce, luckily players are given some tools to help contain the fires--however the tools are limited, and will not be able to protect all of your city.

Prevent as many fatalities as possible, keep your city from burning completely to the ground, and you just might be able to come out on top!

Turbulent roulette for delicious bones...

On your marks! Get set! Woof! Time after time the ball rolls through the gardens with the naughty dogs in pursuit. Where the ball stops, the dogs uncover some tasty bones. Whoever collects the most bones, whether by skill or by luck, will be crowned the leader of the pack. Exciting to the end, because dog-roulette always has a surprising twist.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Der Goldene Kompass: Das Kartenspiel zum Film

item.description:
Players take turns playing cards from their hand to a central pool. The player earns points by playing a card, whose value matches the value of either one or more cards already in the pool, or the sum of several cards already in the pool. In either case, the player wins all the cards in the set and places them in their score pile.

The round ends when the draw pile has been emptied: Points are awarded for the yellow 7, for the most yellow cards, and for the most total cards. In addition, you can win a point for clearing the table.

The game ends after a set number of round.

Re-implements: 

 Scopa
 Gelb gewinnt!

Sometimes the bad guys pull off a big heist, and sometimes the good guys can stop the crime before it happens. But in the long run, it’s all about style.

In Chicago’s Finest, you take the role of the titular boys in blue, or their nemesis, the mob. Both sides are working hard to either perpetuate or prevent crime - but their primary concern is looking sharp.

Players tactically deploy cards representing guys, weapons, tools, and even K9 units in attempt to conjure up precisely enough cool to match the crime of the day. How much style is needed is determined by the Time, Day, Neighborhood, Location, and type of Crime – which change every day. The game lasts seven days.

Chicago’s Finest is quick, free to print out, and different every time you play it. Game mechanics somewhat resemble Blackjack, but with a variable target number, as well as an arsenal of tricks and card synergies that let you manipulate your and your opponent’s card total.

Download the game in the BGG Files section.

Thanks to a nasty computer virus, most of the researchers from University of Chicago’s Department of Temporal Archeology are lost somewhere in time.

In ChronoCrisis, players take on the role of crafty collegiate researchers to collect clues that can lead to the whereabouts and whenabouts of their lost colleagues. The trick, of course, is to minimize interaction with the “natives” and not damage the flow of history.

Players search for clues in five different time periods – Ancient Greece, Legendary Baghdad, Feudal Japan, Elizabethan England, and the Harlem Renaissance – in attempt to deduce and pinpoint the location of the lost time travelers.

Players collect clue cards through detective work, and can also steal clue cards from their unsuspecting opponents. When a player collects a set of clues from the same time period, he or she can attempt to make contact and confirm if the individual they’ve been tracking is indeed a fellow time traveler. The player’s hunches will often be correct. But invariably these hunches are sometimes wrong, and players have to plan ahead to make sure they’re able to deal with feisty natives.

The first player to rescue five lost time travelers wins. The catch, however, is that this target number of five increases whenever a player encounters a native.

ChronoCrisis is a quick, free, print-and-play card game for 2-4 players.

Download the game in the BGG Files section.

Players try to complete a new magic potion by gathering the correct coloured ingredients, which are then stored on shelves on the gameboard. The ingredient collection is based on the luck a die roll, but those that are not needed can also be traded.

Before the magic potion is brewed the colour oracle moves and players have to predict the resulting colour. If correct, the player gets to move forwards and thus move closer to star chamber, where they can claim the coveted magic hat. If the prediction is wrong, everyone gives the concoction an imaginative name... how about "Firefly-juice"?

The game comes with a set of water-soluble Faber-Castell colouring pencils and intends to promote creativity and the communication skills of children.

In the mid-16th Century, Lord Date Masamune is consolidating his power in northeastern Japan. Masamune has decreed that the first person to document the vastness of this new kingdom will be honored with the title of “Shogun’s Cartographer.”

In Cartographer: The Card Game, players are ambitious mapmakers competing to complete a map of Masamune’s kingdom and win a place in the Shogun’s court.

Players hire Explorers and send them in one of the four cardinal directions to survey the lands and take notes toward what will eventually be a map of Masamune’s kingdom. Players may also hire Samurai, and Shinto Priests, who accompany the Explorers and help to fend off Oni, Kappa, Tengu, and other dangerous inhabitants of mythological Japan.

Explorers may also find treasure, be forced into a battle of wits with a sly Kitsune, or suffer the consequences of an earthquake.

Cartographer: The Card Game is a free print-and-play card game for 2-4 players.

Download the game in the BGG Files section.

Cartographer: The Card Game is a precursor to Cartographer: Vision of the Shogun.

name.value: Iwo Jima: Rage Against the Marines

item.description:
Iwo Jima - Rage Against the Marines is a two player game that is included in MMP's "Operations Special Magazine Issue #1." The game is a simulation covering the fighting occurring on the island from February 17 to March 14 1945.

The Game includes rules (8 pages), a half-counter sheet of 88 x 5/8" counters, the game map, a mini-map for hidden Japanese movement, and a screen to prevent prying American eyes.

The game is 9 turns long, American units are regiment-sized, and Japanese units represent about 1,000 men.

Each game turn has four phases, Weather, US Phases (of which there are 7), Japanese Phases (of which there are 5), and an End Phase. The rules are laid out according to the sequence of play, and there is an extra page for special rules, scoring, and how to win.


Reimplements The battle for Iwo-jima first published in Game Journal #16.

item.description:
Each player leads a character that goes around the city and responds to questions about Stockholm. Each correct answer gives 10 "Stockholmscred." The goal is to visit all the districts. When a player has been able to cope with questions for all puzzles, the endgame can begin. At the end, all the players Stockholmscred are counted up and the player with most wins.

Complete description in Swedish can be found at http://www.stockholmsspelet.se/

item.description:
ROC 'n Lol is Dutch game designed for a school (ROC). It is actually a two-in-one-game, since the game can be played in two different ways.

1. Party and play
Can be played by two to five teams of two players each. Each team moves it's pawn by rolling a die and performing different actions (answering questions, guessing words, drawing pictures). Winner is the first team to reach the finish line.

2. Topper Coach
Can be played by 2 to 5 players. Each player has six students that need to graduate. These six students are guided through their education by playing out cards. Winner is the first player graduating all six students.

About the game name:
"ROC" is the name of the school type.
"Lol" is the Dutch word for "fun".

item.description:
From Mike Petty:

Bedlam: The Countdown
This is a resource management and negotiation game set in the dark future. Most simply, it's an auction game where the characters you buy provide the options you'll have for actions on your turn. Instead of using the usual approach with character based card games--when cards refer to broad classes of characters such as "thief" or "wizard"--the cards in Bedlam refer to specific characters and they give the game an excellent sense of narrative. Prepare for some surprises, some backstabbing and plenty of tough decisions.

I know that, as the game's creator, my own opinion doesn't count for much. I have to say this is my favorite game of all that I have created. I'm glad to be able offer it for the first time in this form. I trust expansions and other editions will follow as more people discover the simple system and explore the possibilities it offers.

The game is for three to five players and it can be completed in 45- 60 minutes. You'll need to print and cut out about 50 cards, a player sheet for each player and some counters (if you don't want to use poker chips or other tokens).

The players takes the roles of lawyers that have just started successful careers at well-reputed law firms. As litigation lawyers you will spend all your time processing in the country's public courts. Your want of challenges has lead you to enter into a prestigious bet with your friends. The one that manages to first win a case in the Supreme Court will have the respect of his peers for the rest of her/his career.

To achieve the goal of winning a process in the Supreme Court the players must work their way through the Swedish public court system. After winning processes in six different areas of the law in the municipal courts the players can move up and start processing in the courts of appeal. A process is won by correctly answering a juridical question.

A game based on the Alien/Predator universe, in which the players control humans, aliens, or predators. It is played on a chess board or any similar 8x8 grid. Miniature figures or chits are used to represent the individual combatants. The object of the game is to destroy your opponent’s leader unit. Card play is central to the game. Cards drawn from a common deck are played to cause units to move and attack.

When it comes to card games, you know you're the best. Now prove it with fist-pounding bone-breaking attacks and perfectly timed blocks of the Darkstalkers™ Collectible Card Game.

As part of the Universal Fighting System (UFS), the action flows quickly between players as punches and kicks are thrown and grapples and throws are executed with deadly precision. You are one of the characters from Darkstalkers™ and you will become the champion!

Each booster contains 10 Darkstalkers CCG cards which are 100% compatible with the entire library of UFS collectible card games. Players need at least 1 UFS starter deck to used the cards within.

name.value: Universal Fighting System: Samurai Shodown V
Universal Fighting System: The King of Fighters 2006

item.description:
When it comes to card games, you know you're the best. Now prove it with fist-pounding bone-breaking attacks and perfectly timed blocks of the KING OF FIGHTERS 2006 and the SAMURAI SHOWDOWN Collectible Card Games.

As part of the Universal Fighting System (UFS), the action flows quickly between players as punches and kicks are thrown and grapples and throws are executed with deadly precision. You are one of the characters from KING OF FIGHTERS 2006 or from SAMURAI SHOWDOWN and you will become the champion!

The 60 card starter deck contains everything one player needs to start fighting in the UFS arena, including a rule sheet. It contains 3 exclusive cards, not available anywhere else.

Each booster contains 10 The King of Fighters 2006 and/or Samurai Showdown V CCG cards which are 100% compatible with the entire library of UFS collectible card games. Players need at least 1 UFS starter deck to used the cards within.

In a history that never was, the greatest empires of Earth's past stand at the apex of their glory. In Rome, gladiators do battle in the Circus Maximus. The Pharaohs of the Nile raise great pyramid monuments to their own mortality. China builds its Forbidden City, and in India a young prince sits under a pipal tree and finds Enlightenment. In the north, the furious Vikings launch their long ships for another season of plunder and pillage, and beyond the Great Wall the Mongol clans gaze at the great Empires with greedy eyes. But behind the opulence and grandeur of the empires, beneath the petty border conflicts and barbaric raids, rages a hidden, secret war… the ShadoWar.

Keepers of a forgotten truth, the Order of the Celestial Dawn devote themselves to bringing Enlightenment to all mankind. They are opposed by the Covenant of Twilight, a secret organization bent on using their power to rule all the empires of man. With guile, wisdom, treachery, and stealth they fight in the shadows for the destiny of humanity, turning the course of history towards their own ends.

Throughout this land of mystery and wonder walk men and women possessed of supernatural power and ability. With bodies and minds honed by constant practice, these warriors are the forefront of the ShadoWar.

ShadoWar is a Customizable Card Game.

name.value: Last Stand: The Battle for Moscow 1941-42

item.description:
The Last Stand at Moscow simulates German winter offensive to capture Moscow.

One map 594×841cm
17.2km/Hex
386counters
Unit scale II, X, XX, XXX, KG
10 days/Turn Oct 1941 to Jan 1942

In October 1941, the German Army launched Operation Typhoon - the last major German offensive of the year. In an all-out attempt to defeat Russia and end World War Two, the Germans managed to see the spires of the Kremlin as their high water mark for both this battle and for the war. Over two million men fought in this desperate battle that would decide the war and the future of mankind.

Masahiro Yamazaki, the designer of the MMP games Red Star Rising and Stalingrad Pocket has designed his greatest game on this great conflict- Last Stand; The Battle for Moscow 1941-1942. Using all the tricks in his designer’s bag, Mas has made this titanic struggle playable but without sacrificing a great sense of history. Offering 3 scenarios to show different aspects of the campaign, and a unique way of showing the plight of the Soviet morale as a nation faces possible complete military defeat, all in a manageable size, Last Stand is a game that has no competitor.

As seen in Mas’ other games, Last Stand features an interesting sequence of play:


 A.) German Player Turn
 ) Supply Phase
 a.) Weather
 b.) Reinforcement/Supply Placement
 c.) Receive Air Points
 d.) Combat Unit Supply Check
 e.) Isolated Attrition Check
 f.) Supply Unit Removal (Snow Turns)
 g.) Soviet Morale Chit Pull (if applicable)
 
 ) Movement Phase
 a.) Unit Movement/Overrun
 b.) Supply Unit Consumption
 
 ) Combat Phase
 a.) Resolve Combat
 b.) Remove Supply Units in Expend Mode
 
 ) Soviet Reaction Phase (The Soviet Player is allowed to move and overrun with eligible Mechanized units)
 ) Exploitation Movement (all German units may move again with one half of their movement allowance) 
 
 B.) Soviet Player Turn
 ) Supply Phase
 a.) Reinforcement HQ and Combat Unit Placement
 b.) Receive Air Points
 c.) Combat Unit Supply Check
 d.) Isolated Attrition Check
 e.) Red Army Morale Check
 
 ) Katyusha Gun Phase
 a.) Katyusha movement
 b.) Katyusha Fire
 
 ) Movement Phase
 ) German Reaction Phase (Like the Soviets in his reaction phase, but with different parameters, the German player may conduct reaction move with his eligible Mechanized units).
 ) Combat Phase
 a.) Ski Unit placement
 b.) Resolve Attacks
 
 ) Exploitation Movement (identical to the German Phase)
 


In addition, the game features unknown unit strengths for the Soviet Units, variable and shifting victory conditions, Soviet Army morale breakdown, German variable supply consumption, and of course, substantial weather effects as General Winter arrives as a reinforcement for the Soviet cause.

Perhaps the most unique aspect of Last Stand is the Victory Conditions. As the game begins, neither player knows what they must accomplish to win the game. As the game progresses and the Germans advance towards Moscow, the Germans will find out what it takes to win. Soviet Morale will continue to fall until the Soviets can strike back - and when they do, the damage is healed twofold - but defeat can happen at any moment.

Last Stand features three scenarios of different lengths to give players options depending on how much time they have to play.

Scenario One - the Soviet Counterblow
This scenario covers only the great Soviet Counterattack that pushed the Germans to the brink of defeat in the late Winter 1942. Playing time is about 3-4 hours.

Scenario Two - The Germans Attack
This scenario covers the German attack to defeat the Soviets before winter comes. Playing time is about 5-6 hours.

Scenario Three - the Campaign Game
This scenario covers the entire offensive and the Soviet counterattack. Combining both scenario one and two together, this has a playing time of about 10 hours.

Last Stand components:
One 34 by 22 map 
560 ½" counters 
32 page full color rulebook 
2 player aids

Game Details:
Solitaire Rating: very good to excellent 
Complexity: Medium 
Playing Time: 3-10 hours 
Scenarios: 3 
Game scale: Units are divisions, turns are ten days, and hexes are 17.2 kilometers across.
Four cards of the same design, numbered from 1 to 4, constitute a book. The winner of the game is the player having the most books at the end of play.

This is a roll & move game in which certain spaces allow the player to make a roulette bet, throw craps, play a hand of black jack, or play the slots. The slots are played via flipping cards. The game comes with 100 plastic poker chips in 4 colors. The winner is the first to $20,000 or 1/5 of the chips.
Early baseball game that includes the board, a 60-card deck and 3 markers.

A spelling game from the 1930s, which might best be described as a "free form" Scrabble.

Cards are dealt, and each player spells words, attaching them to any existing words in "crossword" fashion. The first player to get rid of all their cards wins the round, and the other players add the value of their remaining cards to their score. Games ends when someone reaches 100 points, and LOW SCORE wins.

The letter cards, how many of each, and their values:


 Free 2 10 I 2 8 R 4 6
 A 6 8 J 2 4 S 6 6
 B 2 4 K 2 6 T 6 6
 C 4 6 L 6 6 U 4 6
 D 2 4 M 4 6 V 2 4
 E 8 8 N 4 6 W 4 6
 F 2 2 O 6 6 X 2 1
 G 4 2 P 2 6 Y 2 2
 H 4 6 Q 2 2 Z 2 1

Based on the Kittenwar website, this card game sets pairs of kittens against each other to see which is the cutest. Although the basic game is based on War, there are three different variants that take advantage of five different stats per kitten: Agility, Speed, Stealth, Avian Observation Tactics, and Paw to Paw Combat. Each of the 100 cards depicts a full-color photograph of a featured kitten from the website.

Apples to Apples Niños consists of two decks of cards in Spanish: Red Apple cards (persons, places, things, or events) and Green Apple cards (adjectives). Each turn, the current judge selects a Green Apple card and players try to pick a Red Apple card from their hands that best match that the chosen card. The judge then chooses the Red Apple card is most like the word on the Green Apple card. The judge gives the Green Apple card to the player whose Red Apple card was chosen.

Once a player has won a four Green Apple cards, that player wins.

Game lived in the Middle Ages with collection of pieces in which the player assembles his kingdom, which builds castles, farms, villages and abbeys, Wars facing other kingdoms in wars of expansion, suffers attacks by Vikings, witchcraft and black fever, has factor luck by collecting points as well as parts of the game, strategic factor is reasonable.

item.description:
Nation's Treasures is a card game inspired by Lost Cities. 
While retaining the classic Lost Cities 2-player rule, the game is designed with new 3-4 player rule. In new 3-4 player rule:
Cards are separated into 5 decks according to colors.
In the setup, players draw 2 cards randomly and flips the top card of each deck, then chooses to draw 2 cards.
Each time the top card is drawn, you flip up the top card.

Reise nach Moskau is the game of Misha the Bear's travels across the USSR.

Players are dealt a hand of 8 city cards, representing cities in the USSR and 4 action cards which let them take special moves.

The object of the game is to play all your cards by moving from city to city and then return to Moscow when you have no cards in hand. The player that does this first is the winner.

City cards are played just by moving to the corresponding city on the map (players familiar with Wildlife Adventure will see a similarity but this game does not use routes).

Action cards are played instead of moving and allow the player to do things such as fly to any city, force another player to draw an additional city card, or "invite" other players to join you in your city (quite annoying when you are heading to your final destination).

A 2-2 players game based on the Old Chinese Game "Tiger Chess".
A more complex game, with 2 "tigers", and 12 "human".
"human" aim at to capture the tigers, by surrounding the tigers.
"tigers" aim at to eat "human", so that the human cannot capture the tigers.

The Triangle Challenge - A Game of Strategy & Daring

The object for each player is to score the most points by creating triangles where all three end-points match the color of their wooden stacker. The larger the triangle, the larger the point value. The player with the most points after all 20 discs have been played, wins!

The Strategy - Strategy is the key to secretly loading your wooden stacker and selecting which move to make on every turn. Each player controls 5 red and 5 blue discs.

The Dare - Daring is essential to out-fox your opponent on every turn. Try to bluff and trick your opponent into helping you create more triangles of your color to win, without letting yourself be fooled.

Contents: Wooden game board, two wooden stackers, twenty discs (10 blue, 10 red), instructions.

Introduction: If you're like me you only eat at the classiest of joints… you know places that have a napkin dispenser, a tray of sugar packets, and if you're lucky your own bottle of ketchup! No doubt the service is just wonderful too. Friendly, but slow. I created this game to play while waiting for your grease burger you ordered with extra grease.

Materials Required: 25 sugar packets, 2 players and 1 coin. (Don't lose that coin… it's your tip for after the meal!)

Object of the Game: When the coin lands on a player's home packet, that player has won.

Get the full game here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

The first in a series of games that can be carried in your wallet! This is a wild rocket race across your tabletop!

This game is best played on any tabletop littered with objects. These objects become the obstacles on the race course. The players should begin by defining the start line, the course through the obstacles and the finish line. The the racers should be placed power-side up at the start line.

Get the full game here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

For hundreds of years they have watched others enjoy the glory of battle. They have helped heroes rescue the damsel in distress. They have won humans fortunes untold. They have decided the outcome of a million encounters. But never in all that time have they ever entered the battle as the hero or the damsel. Not a single coin has ever been won for them. Never has an encounter been theirs to experience.

At last, polyhedral dice have their chance! In this light tactical wargame, the players pit forces of dice against each other in mortal combat. There are no miniatures; the dice themselves fight their own battles. Now they can enjoy the glory of battle and so can you!

Formula D is a high stakes Formula One type racing game where the players race simulated cars with the hope of crossing the finish line first. This is a re-release of Formula DÃ© with several changes from the original format. Whilst old tracks can be used with the updated Formula D rules, the new game features boards that have an F1 track and a Street Track on the other side. These street tracks each have a novel inclusion or two to add greater theme -

The game mechanisms are a simple race, get to the finish line first! However, players have to use a significant amount of planning, and rely on quite a bit of luck. Each player manages when to shift gears, with each gear providing a different speed. (For example, 4th gear is a die that rolls random numbers from 7 to 12 for spaces moved.) Each turn, players may move up one gear, stay in that gear, or move down gears. This forces players to match possible rolls with the optimum distance for that turn, and hopefully plan ahead. However, speed is not the only issue! Corners have a "stop" rule that requires players to stop once, twice, or three times on that corner in consecutive turns or face a penalty. This creates an effective speed limit to the corners. 
 Of course, things do not always go as planned! Players take penalties if they miss their roll, bump into another car, are blocked by other cars, have to brake heavily, or have to downshift several gears. These are taken off of a car’s attributes (Tire health, Brake wear, Transmission Gears, Body, engine, and Suspension). Losing the maximum in any of these categories will result in elimination, or a severe setback for that car. This requires that players manage their car’s health, plan for their best path, and have good luck on their rolls. This high amount of luck gives the game its family appeal, and lets weaker players have a chance at winning once in a while.

However, the fun does not end with a single race! The rules include the ability to customize your cars, use a pre-generated character, add Slipstreaming (Drafting) rules and road debris, and change tire types to modify your distance rolls. There are also variations for a single lap race, or multiple laps with pit stops to repair some of your damage points. In addition, numerous expansion tracks can be purchased to vary the demands on each driver and car. Each track may also have weather effects (rain) that change car handling and die rolls due to skidding on wet track. This opens up the game for rally rules giving championship points over a number of races.

Formula D adds a few items that are not in the original Formula De: There is the added excitement of illegal racing in the streets of big cities - anything goes! This adds custom cars, nitro acceleration, drifting in the curves, dirty tricks, gun battles, and trash on the road to add more variation. A basic change is the use of a "Dashboard" with movable pegs to manage your car’s attributes instead of the paper forms from Formula De. There are also two sets of pre-painted cars; a Formula 1 set and the Street Race set of stock cars. The street cars come with "Character" profiles to give a bit of role-playing to the game. Finally, the old category of "Fuel" for the car has been renamed Transmission Wear to give a better thematic fit to the effect of multiple downshifting.

The popularity of this game has given it a lot of expansions, some simplifications to the rules (See Formula DÃ© Mini), and a lot of "after market" parts. There are also fan expansions and tracks for the very dedicated player. In many ways, this has become a multiple game system.

item.description: The newest Game by Lizardy for 2-4 players. It is about casting spells in order to change the weather. In fact it is rather abstract strategy game. The author (Krzysztof Matusik) is well known from previous Lizardy games (For example: Romeo and Juliet).

This is an action packed game of starship combat set within the boundaries of the Firestorm Universe. War has erupted in the space surrounding the Terran Worlds and nothing looks set to stop the Invaders. Race after race has been plunged into the abyss of the conflict and no one race has so far been able to stop the invaders. Now the Terran Alliance has been forced to react with the full capability of its military machine.

You control powerful fleets of frigates, cruisers, battleships and transport ships as you fight as a Terran commander, an Invading fleet commander or one of the outlying star systems that has allied itself with the Terrans to combat the threat.

Models are primarily resin with some white metal components. A full color rule book supports the models, along with decks of game cards, templates, tokens, historical background documents and much, much more.

Who will you be? A defender or an invader...

item.description:
London, 1899: in the renowned Diamonds Club meet four successful gemstone dealers in an ambitious competition: they want to equip magnificently their country estates -- with the profit made from the gemstone trade. To do that, they invest their money in mines, mining rights and the latest technologies. The player who has the most valuable park at the end of the game is the Lord of Diamonds!

The goal of the game is to build a magnificent park with many (different) attractions. The game ends, when the first player completes his or her park. Then victory points are scored based on the contents of the parks, technology advancements and achievements gained during the game. The player with the most victory points wins the game.

Diamonds Club is played in turns until the end condition is met by the first player. Each turn is divided into different phases. In the first phase players take turns placing coins on a central board to gain several benefits: mines, ships and prospector rights to gain gemstones, technology advancements or wildlife park attractions for the own park.
To gain the benefit of a square you have to place one coin plus the sum of all vertical and horizontal placed coins. So as the players take turns, the available benefits grow more and more expensive.
Once every player has passed, the players may change a combination of ship, prospector rights and mine into as many gemstones as the lowest value on all of the counters depicts.
In the final phase the players can buy new attractions for their park using the earned gemstones.

As mentioned above, there are several achievements, for example to be the first player having 5 equal attractions, or a special combination of attractions. Those score later extra points for the player who won this. Also, there are several technologies, which could raise the value of woods in the park, increase the gemstone income of the player or increases the number of coins available each round for the player. On the higher levels those technologies also score additional points in the final scoring.

item.description:
So what is it all about? The Uncharted Lands is a fantasy combat game that uses 28mm scale white metal miniatures. But it is also MUCH more than just a range of well sculpted figures.

The Uncharted Lands will act as the backdrop for all of our fantasy games, including our naval combat game.

The first races to be supported are Iron Dwarves and Orc Raiders. But we’re underway with our Humans and Dragon Lords. Shortly we will be making our Halfling Militia available and over time more races from The Uncharted Lands will appear.

We are developing a set of rules for the game and we hope to have more news for you on when these rules will be available. Right now we have 9 packs of miniatures (5 Iron Dwarf and 4 Orc Raiders) complete, each with 4 figures for foot troops or 3 figures for command.

We have greens for new figures, including an Orc commander and his brutish bodyguard and a cannon and crew for the Dwarves. We are busy with the design of our Dragon Lords and Humans, both races we’re sure you’ll like when they arrive.

Over time The Uncharted Lands will grow and new races will begin to unfold. The combination of naval game and land game is a novel one and we’re sure you’ll enjoy both. The Gallery below will give you an idea of what our miniatures look like when painted.

OBJECT OF GAME: The player to make the last legal move wins.

START: Make two piles of l1 stones. Each player rolls the die. Whoever rolls the highest value makes the first
move.

PLAY: Each player starts his/her turn by flipping a coin. If the coin lands heads up then the turn must be TAKO
HI. And if the coin lands tails up the turn must be TAKO LO. TAKO HI and TAKO LO affect how many stones
the player can remove from each pile in this turn. Then the player rolls the die and makes note of the value. Next
the player must make a legal move. Legal moves consist of:
1. Taking any number of stones from one pile.
2. Taking an equal number of stones from both piles.
3. Using an option move.

THE DESIGNER SAYS: As far as I can recall this is the first game I created that I actually committed to paper. I believe I created this game in 1992 or 1993. Based loosely on a mathematical game called Tsianshidsi, TAKO is a silly time wasting game.

According to the rules sheet, TAKO is pronounced take-o.

Full Rules Here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

A silly little pirate game for 2 players! 
Goal: Arrrgghh! To be the pirate with the most booty at the end of the game, of course! This is done by creating rows of 3 or more coins.

Full Game Here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

(from Decision Games website:)

Highway to the Reich is a tactical simulation of the largest airborne operation in history. Over 35,000 men belonging to 1st Allied Airborne Army dropped from the skies of Holland. Their objective: capture and hold a highway. The result: a salient into German territory that lacked only the last objective, and was thus a tragic defeat.

The 2,000-plus counters detail Brereton's Airborne Corps of three divisions, the units of Brian Horrocks's 30th Corps, and Model's scattered and dishevelled forces at company level for infantry; battery level for artillery, anti -tank and anti-air; and troop level for tank and armored cars.

The four maps cover the area from the front along the Meuse-Escaut Canal to the land, nearly 200 hexes away, surrounding the Arnhem Highway Bridge. Each map is positioned to cover the operational area of one airborne division. That allows one-division scenarios.

The system focuses on the interaction of two variables: fire power and morale. The structure of the game turns is simple, with each player turn divided into a Command Communications Phase and a Maneuver Phase. All the activities of each formation are completed before those of another are begun. Attacks proceed with a preliminary barrage, fire attack by maneuver companies, and then close action with tanks or assault troops. All activities involve comparisons of involved units' capabilities. Those variables create the framework within which the players operate.

Optional rules focus on hidden movement and multi-player variations, as well as giving the Allied player the opportunity to execute his own operational plan.

item.description: Balancing Bob sits atop a ladder mounted on a pivoting base. Each player has three plastic paint cans that hook onto the ladder. Based on a die roll, players move their cans up the ladder and eventually hang them on one of Bob's outstretched feet. The first player to get all three of their cans onto Bob's feet without tipping over the ladder wins.

Bee Bops features a motorized flower patch. When activated, the flowers' pedals open to reveal "nectar disks". Each player has, according to the rules, a "stick-on trigger action bee". The trigger extends an arm with a suction cup at its end, which is used to collect the nectar disks. The player who retrieves the most nectar wins.

This children's game requires no reading, but helps to learn the animal names. Each player is given a "character card" depicting an elephant, giraffe, tiger, or zebra. Players attempt to create a copy of their animal out of four square tiles. The tiles start stacked face down on cards depicting one of eight other animals. On their turn, a player spins a spinner to determine which animal's stack they may draw from to find one of their missing animal pieces. The player completing their animal first wins.

Jeson Mor ("9 horses") is a two-player board game played on a 9x9 checkerboard that originates in Mongolia. This game was described in "The Encyclopedia of Chess Variants" (by David Pritchard).

Each horse moves like the Chess knight.
The goal of the game is to move one of your own horses to the middle cell of the board and then to move that horse outside the middle cell.

A player also wins if he captures all opponent's horses.

item.description:
Humanity has been at each other's throats since time immemorial. Now in another galaxy humans wage war amongst themselves again but this time with the aid of alien technology found on other planets. Ascending Empires offers a nice mixture of building exploring and development along with combat via a simple dexterity element. Ascending Empires is sure to sate the desire for a space empire building game that plays simply yet deeply.

The last survivors of the Human race have fled to a new galaxy in fear of annihilation at the hands of an unstoppable enemy. Now, having discovered the ruins of four long dead civilizations spread across the stars, the race to develop technology based on the alien relics has begun. Humans will once again ascend to the stars to claim the galaxy.

Players will colonize new worlds by building colonies, cities, and research facilities. They will develop new Technologies, and build up fleets of Starships. Ascending Empires is a fast paced game that utilizes a dexterity based Starship movement and combat system, and allows for many different strategies to be explored.

item.description:
Game parts:

12 1/2 x 15 1/2 heavy folded board
Six pointed star spinner
3 wisemen on camels
3 shepherds

Game board shows the location of 145 Historic Places Famous in Bible History. The object of the game is to travel the roads and the first to get all their pieces to Bethlehem first wins.

Skedoodle was published in Sid Sackson's A Gamut of Games.

It is a mathematical game where a master number is chosen among the following: 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 or 9 and, starting with a number from 1 to 30, players try to obtain the master number by the following operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication or division of the two digits of the chosen number. Players also score with a number that contains the master number written on it. The first player may not start the game with a scoring number. Then the next player must write another number using these same operations or by doubling, halving, squaring or taking the square root of the previous number. Each number from 1 to 30 may not be used more than once. The games ends when no further unused number between 1 to 30 can be derived from the actual number by the rules.

This game was presented to Sid Sackson by it author Father Daniel, with whom Sid Sackson exchanged correspondence about games in general.

item.description:
Nun Bowling, It's Sinfully Fun!

For 1 or more players

To bowl is human; the perfect game: divine.
You always knew sinning could be fun, but you never realized how much fun-until now. These STERN, ruler-armed, saintly sisters are just asking for retribution, whether you have Catholic school flashbacks or simply don't like their fashion sense. Strike back with the included 10 nun pins, ball of hellfire and 32-page book.

Contents: 36 hexagonal tiles, each with 6 triangles showing pictures of Paddington in different colours.

Before you start, choose one of the figures shown on the side of the box. This should be used as model. All cards are divided amongst the players. The youngest player starts by laying one card face-up on the table. The player on his left-hand side then takes one of his cards and puts this next to the "open" card, in such a way that the previously chosen figure can be made. The cards have to be laid out face to face. When a player is unable to lay a card on the table, he has to skip a turn. The first player to lose all his cards is the winner.

Contents:
- 1 book of rules
- 4 grids and 4 hiding screens of same colour
- 324 oval coins with figures
- 324 squared coins with figures
- 4 scoring boards and 4 pawns

The purpose is to be the quickest to solve a common Sudoku problem, each player having his own color for grid and numbers. The first to solve his grid wins 3 points, the second 2 points, and the third 1 point. First to raise 9 points is the winner.

The book of rules have 100 grids and solutions.

Sangre y Fuego (Blood and Fire) is a solo game, of tactical urban fighting in Spanish Civil War.
Easy print and play recreates the battles for Belchite and Teruel.
